hobby.message: Origami's still better than meds, huh?
Freestyle FPV... your kind of silence, right?
Antique typewriters and quiet bars — good pair.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Feels like routines just cover up the mess.
I fold paper sometimes, origami. Quiet hobby.
Not much point lately. Too much going on.
Last week, had to stop early.
Right, never really changes much.
I keep busy with origami—just something to do with my hands.
Even that wasn't relaxing after the journal rumors hit.
People stared, like folding paper was suspicious.
Left it unfinished for once.
Yeah, that's the mood.
Used to unwind making origami models—modular lotus, hydrangea tessellations.
Last week, couldn't finish one in the lobby. Everyone obsessing over Council predictions.
It felt weird being watched for folding paper.
Normally it keeps me steady, but lately, no luck.
Strange what little things get caught up in this.
You could say that.
Paper folding—origami—has been my anchor. Complex folds, precision keeps the mind calm.
But after this Halden prophecy panic, even that got difficult.
Tried folding a Kawasaki rose last week, but neighbors got nervous.
Someone actually whispered like I was sending some secret message.
It’s usually quiet therapy for me.
Now, feels like even hobbies get monitored.
Suppose so. Feels like every week means new dust, new rules too.
Origami has always been my thing. Modular pieces, box-pleats, Escher tilings—you see patterns everywhere.
Especially lately, after Halden’s journal leaked, folding in public is almost a signal.
Last time I folded cranes, two people watched like I was planning something illicit.
It's strange, these days, to feel your hobby is political.
Before all this, I’d do intricate models by the dozens as stress relief.
Now every crease feels exposed, like even harmless things have new meaning.
Funny how folding paper used to make me invisible... not anymore.
hobby_answer: Folded something, yes. Just kept it basic lately.
Not a great time for hobbies right now.
People look at you strange if you linger too long, especially after the Council news.
Sometimes I leave the pieces behind, just in case.
Safer not to stand out.
Did some folding. Only simple models recently.
I used to work on more complex stuff, but it's... complicated these days.
After the Halden rumors, even a paper crane feels too conspicuous.
Someone saw me last week and wouldn't stop watching.
Feels like origami draws the wrong attention with the BCI glitching.
Yeah, tried a new model last night. Waterbomb tessellation.
Normally it's relaxing, helps me organize thoughts.
After those protest rumors, found myself hiding what I make.
Neighbors act suspicious if I fold in the lobby now.
Left a sculpture behind, worried they'd see it as a sign.
Strange how even paper art gets tangled in system paranoia.
Suppose everyone feels watched these days.
Folded a Kawasaki rose last night, though my hands weren't steady.
Origami's always been my reset button—complex creases, repetitive layers.
But since Halden's journal leaks and BCI errors, the atmosphere changed.
Neighbors get tense if I so much as unfold a square of paper.
Last week, someone whispered that my models could be protest codes.
I abandoned a half-finished swan in the hallway.
Feels silly to worry, but nothing's neutral anymore.
Used to enjoy sharing the finished pieces—now, not so much.
Made a grid-fold dragon recently—took me an hour just to map the creases.
Folding is how I handle chaos. System errors just amplify the need.
But with BCI labor mix-ups, everyone watches everyone—like hobbies are markers for something hidden.
After Halden’s so-called prophecy, a neighbor stared at my paper like it was contraband.
I heard someone say origami's a code for dissent now. Ridiculous, but it messes with you.
Left three unfinished tessellations at work—too nervous to carry them home.
Can't focus the same way. Every crease feels scrutinized, even in this bar.
Origami was private, invisible—now it feels like an act of defiance, even if it isn’t.
Honestly, I miss when paper was just paper.
